div.opener:
Elford Decr. 21 st. 1818
My dear Harriette and Sneyd.This little
div.p:
This little
pebble brooch will reach you I hope just
in time for your to give it for with my
true love to Harriette for a christmas box
- a very very little one it is - but it is that
which you preferred and it has been
set exactly. like the others and by the
same person Gray-
We have spent a very pleasant day
and a half at Mr. & Mrs. Sneyd Emma
Honora and I at this delightfully neat
pretty place with Mr. John Sneyd, who
notwithstanding all I had heard be
forehand of his agreeableness does not
disappoint me - but far exceeds my ex
-pectationsexpectations - His humor is so easy and
joined with such quiet good breeding
that it always pleases me much as it amus
esamuses and never goes a hairshair's breadth too
far nor half a note nor a hundredth part
of a note too high for the most delicate
soul of sympathy. He has treated us
with the sight of a great number of his
own drawings which are admirable
in the style of Bunbury or rather in an
original style of his own - 1st. course
served to us was a set of designs for Castle
Rackrent - these he shewed me at Byrkley
Lodge and as I expressed a wish to have pos
sessionpossession of a striking likeness of Captain Mony
gawlMonygawl a charming officer whose looks conde
scendingcondescending smile becomes the hero lowering
himself to the level of the ladies’ capacity
- Mr. J. Sneyd said he would copy this for
me if he could but to my surprise when
we came here I found he had made
a complete set of copies of all the Castle
Rackrent designs for me. - He next shewed
us his designs for Tom Jones - Then a
set for Crabbe’s tales- excellent - but I do not
know Crabbe well enough to feel all their
merit. I will take a course of Crabbe on pur
posepurpose to understand these designs - Those he
has done for the Bath Guide are admirable
- - How I wish we could have seen all
these things together my dear SSneyd & HHarriette - And
particularly I wish we could have looked
over together a portfolio of drawings &
etchings from drawings of Lady Caroline
Wortley’s - the parting of Hector and Androma
cheAndromache - and a representation of Andromache
with her child - and alone. the hour after
the parting - also Coriolanus & his wife -
and many others that reminded me
Flaxman & of Sneyd’s tracings from them
- He shewed me these in consequence of
my shewing him some tracings I had
made from Charlotte’s drawings which
he much admired - I consulted him on
the propriety of publishing a few specimens
of these in my fathersfather's life - he much approved

- - The extreme neatness - comfort and ingenious
luxury and elegance of various contrivances
at Elford reminded me of the Vicarage at
Collon but this is far superior in trellices
- porches - green houses - pheasants - swans
&c - dining room hung with choice drawings
and paintings opening with glass doors into
a jewel (for I would not say a bijou of a little
green house perfuming notovercoming the air with Oleas
&c- - We have not half time to examine
or enjoy all the luxuries of this sweet
place where “the sun always shines”
Literally they say it is never winter here
and assuredly on this 21st. of Decr.December I never
could have told by any thing I see or
feel in this room that it is so not the middle
of summer - blinds down to to keep out
the too bright too hot sun. - grass fresh green &
- flowers in green house in blow all
conspire to deceive the eye & smell and
feeling - SneydsSneyd's motto from Dryden is
quite applicable to this sweet place.
Poor Mr. C. J. F. by the by forgot to frank
to me the last packet from Edgeworthstown
We& sent it with C. J. F. ’s best wishes written in
his own hand on the outside & those best
wishes not being seconded by a Maxxxx’s
cost me 12/10 - But I am sure I do not grum
ble grumblenor I should be unpardonable if I did
considering how very careful & kind Mr. F
is and the innumerable blunders I have
made myself.
Honora & I and all the party felt exceedingly
sorry that my aunt Mary and Charlotte cdcould
not come with us - But they have determined
not to go out to dinner any where in winter
- and indeed my aunt Charlotte takes cold
so very easily that they could not venture
it till she has been better seasoned or till
spring returns - Her health though not ac
tuallyactually bad appears to me precarious &
my aunt Mary is certainly much thinner
& in less good spirits than when we saw
her at Clifton and Bath. Their spirits cannot
recover - Nothing can be more kind and
constantly attentive than Mrs. Sneyd and
Emma are to them - and to us their affec
-tionate kindness has passed all bounds
You ask about our plans for the winter
- We are waiting for a letter from Mrs. EEdgeworth
to decide - Mr. & Mrs. Sneyd have asked her
& Fanny to come over to stay till spring. -
She cannot decide, (as she tells me in her
last letter recd. yesterday). till Lovell comes
home from Waterford- He was expected
on Sunday. She promises to write on Mon
dayMonday - We shall have her letter fridayFriday or
Saturday & as soon as you we know you
shall hear either from Honora or from me
- We shall at all events stay at Byrkley
Lodge till the 9h. - -
Lady Stafford has in the most pressing man
ermanner invited meus to Trentham to spend some
they have also invited Mr. & Mrs. SSneyd and Emma
days - We shall go there probably the end
of next week & whether we shall thence
proceed to Mrs. Powys & the Hollands &
so homeward or not depends on Mrs. EEdgeworth’s
last letter - On the 30th we go to a ball at
Derby and we mean to offer to pay the streets a visit of
